questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient undergoes general anaesthesia for abdominal surgery. After intubation, the anesthesiologist needs to confirm that the endotracheal tube (ETT) is correctly placed in the trachea. Which of the following is considered the most reliable method for confirming correct ETT placement?

options.label: B
options.text: Visual condensation in the endotracheal tube

questions.explanation:
Signs of correct endotracheal tube placement
  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by waveform capnography (most reliable sign)
  • Symmetrical chest rise (Option D)
  • Auscultation of bilateral breath sounds (Option A)
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube (Option B)
  • Large exhales of tidal volume

questions.text: A 4-year-old patient with respiratory distress is initiated on High-flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC). Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding HFNC?

options.label: A
options.text: Provides warmed and humidified gas to the airway.

options.label: B
options.text: It can generate low levels of positive airway pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: Improved mortality rate in COVID patients

questions.correct_answer: C. Limits the maximum FiO2 to 60%.
questions.explanation:
High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC)

Non-invasive Ventilation (NIV)

Delivers a high flow of warmed and humidified oxygen through nasal cannulas

Uses face masks or nasal masks to provide positive pressure ventilation

Mainly helpful in Type I respiratory failure

Used as 1st line management in Type II respiratory failure

Nasal Cannula" data-author="NA" data-hash="506" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="December2024" height="500" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/ITOP0C9IpOLBXktJOIUE1735013140.png" width="500" />

questions.text: A 72-year-old female presents to the emergency department in severe respiratory distress, with an oxygen saturation of 78% on room air, tachypnea, and altered consciousness. She has a 3-day history of fever and cough, suggesting community-acquired pneumonia. What is the most appropriate intervention for ensuring adequate oxygenation?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective:
  • ➤ High-Flow Devices: High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC), Venturi mask Low-Flow Devices: Nasal Prongs, Simple Face Mask, Non-Rebreather Mask (NRBM)
  • ➤ High-Flow Devices: High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC), Venturi mask
  • ➤ High-Flow Devices:
  • ➤ Low-Flow Devices: Nasal Prongs, Simple Face Mask, Non-Rebreather Mask (NRBM)
  • ➤ Low-Flow Devices:

Type of mask

Nasal Prong

Face Mask

NRBM

Flow rate

1 to 6 L

6 to 10 L

10 to 15 L

FiO2

25 to 45%

35 to 60%

65 to 95 %

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He is unconscious with an inadequate airway and requires immediate management. Which of the following is the most appropriate method for determining the correct size of the airway as shown in the image below?

options.label: A
options.text: Angle of the mouth to the tragus

options.label: B
options.text: Angle of the mouth to the suprasternal notch

options.label: C
options.text: Tip of the nose to the suprasternal notch

options.label: D
options.text: Tip of the nose to the tragus

questions.correct_answer: D. Tip of the nose to the tragus
questions.explanation:
Nasopharyngeal airway

Guedel airway (Oropharyngeal)

Placed through nose

Placed through mouth

Prevents back falling of tongue

Prevents back falling of tongue

Size is calculated by distance between tip of the nose and tragus

Size is calculated by distance between angle of mouth and tragus

Contraindicated in skull fracture and bleeding disorders

Contraindicated in presence of gag reflex

questions.text: An intern in the ICU witnesses a patient suddenly become breathless and collapse, prompting a code blue. After resuscitation, the senior doctor asks the intern about the significance of the equipment shown in the image. Which of the following is NOT a significance of this equipment?

options.label: C
options.text: Can be used during ventilator failure.

questions.correct_answer: D. Can deliver high-flow supplemental oxygen
questions.explanation:
Advantages

Disadvantages

  • Compressible reservoir automatically expands upon release.
  • Ubiquitous for patient transport (Option A).
  • Suitable for CPR (cardiopulmonary resuscitation) (Option B)
  • Can be utilized as emergency back-up (anesthesia machine, ventilator or oxygen supply failure). (Option C)
  • Require high fresh gas flows to achieve a high Fio2
  • Exhaled moisture can cause valve sticking
  • Exhaled gas into the atmosphere can lead to local contamination (contaminated expiratory gases)
  • Can cause barotrauma or gastric insufflation (high inspiratory pressures)
  • Increase the work of breathing during spontaneous ventilation (generate resistance).

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of COPD and chronic smoking arrived at the emergency department in a semi-conscious state, showing an oxygen saturation of 78% on room air. Resuscitation efforts were initiated right away. What is the function of the component depicted in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Parts

Function

Reservoir bag (self-inflating)

Provides additional oxygen supply (Option C ruled out)

Mask

Creates a seal over the patient’s mouth and nose to ensure effective delivery of air from the bag

Oxygen port

Allows for the connection of supplemental oxygen

One way valve (Fish mouth or unidirectional or Ruben’s valve)

Prevents rebreathing (prevents exhaled air from re-entering the bag)

Pressure valve

Prevents over-inflation of the lungs (Option B ruled out)

Ventilation bag

Deliver breaths to the patient, providing ventilation (Option A ruled out)

Inlet valve

Allows ambient air to enter the ventilation bag

Outlet valve

Vents oxygen if fresh gas flow is excessive

questions.text: A 30-year-old female scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia experiences a sudden increase in heart rate (130 bpm), rapidly rising end-tidal CO2 levels, elevated body temperature, and severe muscle rigidity, especially in the extremities. Which of the following capnogram patterns is indicative of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Capnogram pattern

Description

Seen in

fin pattern" data-author="NA" data-hash="485" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="December2024" height="200" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/b18QkghradMde31RGDud1735008974.png" width="300" />

Shark fin pattern: Due to increased upslope of phase III

(Option A)
  • Bronchospasm
  • COPD
soda lime" data-author="NA" data-hash="489" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="December2024" height="200" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/1wHi1X8VO0QzwgaWtskI1735009388.png" width="300" />

Above the baseline (high base value)

Exhausted soda lime

Abrupt decrease in EtCO2 values.

Venous air embolism

Reduced height of EtCO2 values

Hyperventilation

Curare notch: clefts during Phase III.

(Option C)

Resumption of spontaneous breathing.

(Next step: Muscle relaxation)

Flat capnograph: ETCO2 range: zero

(Option D)
  • Esophageal intubation
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Tube displacement
  • Disconnected circuit

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department in respiratory distress. The healthcare team decides to utilise capnography to monitor her end-tidal carbon dioxide (EtCO₂) levels as part of her assessment. Which of the following does EtCO₂ NOT assess?
questions.explanation:
Phases

Description

Phase I

Exhalation of dead space gas

Phase II

Expiratory upstroke, where transitional gas between the airways and alveoli is sampled, leading to an increase in CO₂ levels..

Phase III

Alveolar Plateau, characterized by a stable pCO₂ level that reflects the gas exchange occurring in the alveoli.

Phase 0

Inspiratory downstroke, where there is a sharp decrease in pCO₂ as fresh, inspired gas washes out the remaining CO₂ at the sampling site.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is undergoing general anaesthesia for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The anesthesiologist is monitoring the patient’s ventilation using capnography. The capnograph shows the following waveform. What does the plateau phases represent in the capnography waveform?

options.label: B
options.text: Expiration of air from the trachea

options.label: D
options.text: Exhalation of air from dead space

questions.correct_answer: A. Expiration of air from alveoli
questions.explanation:
Phase

Description

Corresponds to

Phase 0

Baseline

Inspiration and end of expiration.

Phase I

Initial part of exhalation

Exhalation of dead space gas.

Phase II

Transitional phase

Exhalation of transitional gas between airways and alveoli.

Phase III

Plateau phase

Exhalation of alveolar CO2.

Alpha Angle (α)

Transition from Phase II to Phase III

Change from mixed gas to alveolar CO2.

Beta Angle (β)

Transition from Phase III to Phase 0

End of exhalation and beginning of inspiration.

questions.text: Match the following Laryngeal mask airways (LMA) with their corresponding images. i. Classic LMA a. ii. Proseal LMA b. iii. Fast Track LMA c. iv. Supreme LMA d. v. I-gel LMA e.
questions.correct_answer: B. i-c, ii-a, iii-d, iv-e, v-b
questions.explanation:
First Generation

Second Generation
  • Classic LMA
  • Flexometallic
  • LMA unique
  • Proseal LMA
  • Supreme LMA
  • I-gel LMA

Type of LMA

Description

Classic LMA
  • Silicone mask (oval)
  • Inflatable (sits in the hypopharynx)
  • Forms a seal around the periglottic tissues.
  • Has a risk of aspiration.









 

Proseal LMA

LMA " data-author="Ignis" data-hash="451" data-license="CC BY SA 3.0" data-source="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:ProSeal_Laryngeal_Mask_Airway_inflated_001.jpg" data-tags="December2024" height="205" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/f8XWvlCxq2pBuMNGwwU61734962233.png" width="276" />

  
  • Components:
    • Posterior Cuff: Enhances the seal around the larynx for adequate positive pressure ventilation (PPV).
    • Gastric Drainage Tube: Allows placement of an orogastric tube to isolate the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.
  • Bite Block: Protects the airway device from being bitten, maintaining airway patency.

Fast Track or Intubating LMA
  • Facilitate endotracheal intubation through the LMA device.
  • We can pass the endotracheal tube through this to secure difficult airway

Supreme LMA
  • Material: PVC (polyvinyl chloride)
  • It fits easily and offers superior sealing (compared to other LMAs)
  • It prevents aspiration (as it contains a gastric drainage tube)
  • Integrated bite block (Protects the airway device from being bitten, ensuring airway patency)

I-gel LMA

LMA " data-author="CYP3A42D6" data-hash="694" data-license="CC BY SA 4.0" data-source="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Masques_laryng%C3%A9s-_LMA_Unique_et_I-gel.jpg" data-tags="January2025" height="500" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/bOWz2Nt1C6N6pJee20bd1736513718.png" width="200" />

 
  • Material: Silicon (Helps to grip the pharynx)
  • Balloon and cuff are absent (gel occluder)
  • Temperature regulated LMA
  • Prevent aspiration (gastric port) and Bite block.

 

LMA unique

LMA (1)" data-author="CYP3A42D6" data-hash="695" data-license="CC BY SA 4.0" data-source="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Masques_laryng%C3%A9s-_LMA_Unique_et_I-gel.jpg" data-tags="January2025" height="434" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/tyj1KUlh1X4YhPrGBrL01736513825.png" width="166" />

Material: PVC (polyvinyl chloride)

questions.text: What is the primary advantage of using the endotracheal tube shown in the image below?

options.label: C
options.text: Improved patient comfort during long procedures

options.label: D
options.text: Facilitated access to the surgical site in maxillofacial procedures

questions.correct_answer: D. Facilitated access to the surgical site in maxillofacial procedures
questions.explanation:
North Ring-Adair-Elwyn

South Ring-Adair-Elwyn

Used in maxillofacial or dental surgery and as an alternative to tracheostomy for weaning from respiratory support.

Used in Head and neck surgery, ophthalmic surgery.

questions.text: A 36-year-old with a suspected cervical spine injury is brought to the emergency department in respiratory distress, requiring urgent intubation. Which of the following endotracheal tubes is preferred for this patient?
A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department in Respiratory distress. What is the appropriate size of the endotracheal tube to intubate the child?
questions.explanation:
ETT size (mm) = Age (years)​/4 + 4

Age

Internal Diameter

length

Term-Neonate

3 mm (uncuffed)

9 cm

1 Year Old

4 mm (uncuffed)

10 cm

Child (>1 Year)

Age/4 + 4 mm (uncuffed)

Age/2 + 12 cm

Adult

> 7 mm

18-22 cm

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is undergoing elective surgery under general anaesthesia. During laryngoscopy for intubation, the anesthesiologist visualised the airway, as shown in the image below. According to the Cormack-Lehane classification, what grade is assigned to this view?
questions.explanation:
Grade

Description

Grade I

The entire laryngeal aperture is visible

Grade II

Only the posterior portion of the laryngeal aperture is visible

Grade III

Only the epiglottis is visible

Grade IV

Neither the epiglottis nor the larynx is visible

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with gallstones and is scheduled for a cholecystectomy. During the preoperative assessment, the anaesthetist notes the patient's airway, as visualised in the image below. According to the Mallampati classification, which class does this fall into?
questions.explanation:
Class

description

Class I

The Pillars, uvula, soft and hard palate are visible. (mnemonic PUSH)

Class II

The soft palate, faucial pillars (upper part) and portion of uvula is visible.

Class III

The soft palate and base of uvula is visible.

Class IV

Only the hard palate is visible.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese female has been experiencing excessive vaginal bleeding for two months, and an ultrasound revealed uterine fibroids. She is scheduled for a hysterectomy. What is the preferred position for laryngoscopy in this case?

A 6-year-old child was brought in for an elective tonsillectomy in the operating theatre. During the procedure, the anaesthetist asked the junior resident about the appropriate laryngoscopy and its blades. Which type of laryngoscope is most preferred for this case?
questions.explanation:
Macintosh Laryngoscope

(Option C)

Miller Laryngoscope

(Option B)

McCoy Laryngoscope

(Option A)

Blade

Curved shape


 

Straight shape

Curved with levering tip

Use

In adults

In children (large epiglottis)

It can be used in both adults and children.
